mammals.question: Camels store water in their humps
mammals.explanation: Their humps are actually fat stores, which look droopy if the animals’ bodies burn that fat when food is scarce.

mammals.question: Giraffes only sleep for 30 minutes
mammals.explanation: According to research from the European Sleep Research Society, giraffes actually sleep 4.6 hours a day.

mammals.question: Opossums hang from their tails
mammals.explanation: Baby opossums can hang from their tails for a couple of seconds, but adults are too heavy and only use their tails to help keep their balance while using their legs to climb.

mammals.question: Bats are blind
mammals.explanation: Many fruit bats don’t even echolocate at all. In fact, they have particularly sharp vision.

mammals.question: Bulls get mad when they see the color red
mammals.explanation: Bulls are actually colorblind to red and green. What really gets them riled up during a bullfight is the cape’s movement, and they’re more likely to charge at an object that’s moving the most, no matter what color it is.

mammals.question: Porcupines can shoot their quills
mammals.explanation: Quills are mixed onto their back, sides, and tail and lay flat unless they are feeling threatened. They do detach easily when touched though.

mammals.question: Humans evolved from chimpanzees.
mammals.explanation: Humans and chimpanzees shared a common ancestor millions of years ago

mammals.question: Humans and chimpanzees have identical genes of over 98%
mammals.explanation: Humans and chimpanzees has uncanny similarities but both has evolved into two distinctly separate species in 'ape' family tree.

mammals.question: Dogs can only see in black and white
mammals.explanation: Their vision is limited but they definitely do not see things in black and white, their vision ranges from dark blue to grey to dark and light yellow from spectrum

mammals.question: Raccoons like clean food, that's why they wash it before eating it
mammals.explanation: Raccoons have extremely sensitive front feet and they appear to get more tactile information when their paws are wet than when they are dry, so when water is available they tend to turn their food over repeatedly before eating it.

mammals.question: Dogs sweat through their tongues
mammals.explanation: Dog pants to evaporate moisture from their tongues, nasal passages and lining of teir lungs, which helps them to cool down

mammals.question: An elephant is only animal that can not jump
mammals.explanation: Yes an elephant can not jump and so are others like Rhinoceros, Hippopotamus, Manatees and Seals

mammals.question: Cats are color blind
mammals.explanation: Both cats and dogs can see in blue and green, and they can see better in low light situations, for example reds and pinks would appear more green to cats

mammals.question: We humans use only 10 percent of our brains
mammals.explanation: We humans virtually speaking every part of our brain and most of our brain is active almost always

mammals.question: Polar bear fur is white
mammals.explanation: Their fur is not entirely white, they actually have black skin and translucent fur, which appears to be white due to its lack of pigmentation combined with way light reflects off bears snowy white surroundings

mammals.question: Bats want to suck your blood
mammals.explanation: Bats don not suck any human beings blood, rather they have an anti clotting enzyme in their saliva that helps keep blood flowing

mammals.question: Anteaters eat ants through their nose
mammals.explanation: It’s a myth that an anteater will consume ants through its nose. Instead, anteaters use their claws to rip open anthills and then use their long tongues to eat the insects.

mammals.question: Lemmings commit suicide
mammals.explanation: No, they don't. Not ever. The erroneous notion that lemmings catapult themselves off cliffs en masse apparently got major traction from a 1958 Academy Award-winning Disney nature documentary called "White Wilderness".

mammals.question: Bears hibernate
mammals.explanation: Bears don't hibernate, however, they go into torpor or a deep sleep, during the winter. The difference between the two is that animals easily wake up from noises in torpor, and their body temperature is still relatively high.

mammals.question: Mice only eat cheese
mammals.explanation: A popular myth portrayed in many kids’ cartoons is a mouse always seeking a chunk of cheese to eat. While mice will eat just about anything available, they prefer sweet, sugary foods over cheese.

birds.question: owls are wise birds
birds.explanation: though owls are used as symbol of wisdom they have smaller brains and they are not as smart as Crows and Ravens

birds.question: ostriches sometimes Flop on ground
birds.explanation: ostriches when feel Threaten sometimes Flop on ground

birds.question: penguins can fall backwards when they look up
birds.explanation: it was due to an account when pilots saw penguins tumbling over when looked skywards, but in reality Penguins have ability to hold their footing even when they look up at planes

birds.question: bald eagle got its name from because of it's light-colored head gives it a 'bald' appearance
birds.explanation: it's more related to an old english word 'Balde' which means color white, is source of this name 'bald eagle', which means white headed eagle and nothing to do with appearance of baldness

birds.question: owls eyes are fixed in their eyes sockets
birds.explanation: unlike humans, an owl can not move their eyes from side to side, which in turn developed to a greater head turning capability as they evolved and adapted

birds.question: birds sings because they are happy
birds.explanation: male birds sings to signal others male birds to stay away as a form of aggression, and female birds like those male birds who can sing very often and have complex songs

birds.question: birds are stupid
birds.explanation: birds can recognize relatives they haven’t seen in years, and recognize a neighbor or a stranger just by its voice, remember the location of food they hid away months earlier, and even use things as tools

birds.question: Owls can spin their heads 360 degrees
birds.explanation: Owls are limited to turning their heads 270 degrees in one direction.

birds.question: Turkeys can't fly
birds.explanation: They’re pretty much built to stay on the ground, but wild turkeys can take to the air. They usually don’t go further than 100 yards, but they can travel at 55mph

birds.question: All turkeys gobble
birds.explanation: Not all turkeys gobble. It’s almost exclusively the males, or toms, that get their gobble on.

birds.question: Vultures stalk living animals
birds.explanation: It’s not true that vultures stalk living animals that they know are about to die. In reality, they just have excellent senses, which helps them find food—which, in their case, is typically already-dead creatures

birds.question: Hens don't have teeth
birds.explanation: You may have heard the idiom “rare as hen’s teeth,” but according to a study published in 2006, hens can grow teeth. Around 70-80 million years ago, birds had chompers. They went away, but the genes are still there.

birds.question: A duck's quack does not echo
birds.explanation: The myth that a duck’s quack doesn’t echo is false. All sounds echo, it’s just that a duck’s quack is usually very quiet.

fishes.question: there is a species of Jellyfish doesn't technically perishes and thus immortal
fishes.explanation: a species of Jellyfish known as Turritopsis dohrnii, essentially an immortal sea creature that revert back into juvenile state after adulthood, so it can live alongside its offspring!!

fishes.question: sharks can smell blood from miles away
fishes.explanation: sharks have a highly enlarged portion of brain for smelling odors, and though they smell their prey from far but not from miles but few football fields away at best

fishes.question: any sharks that stop swimming will suffocate and die
fishes.explanation: all sharks lack swim bladder, so when they stop swimming they fall into bottom of ocean floor, and their bodies are so incompressible that it doesn't harm them, they can always ascent or descent for oxygen when needed

fishes.question: farmed fish is not safe to eat
fishes.explanation: farmed fishes are both safe and healthy to eat, diets and environment those fishes live are monitored throughout their life span

fishes.question: farmed fish does not taste as good as wild fish
fishes.explanation: it's a matter of preference, while some enjoy wild fishes, and others enjoy farmed dishes as well, moreover they are both healthy for you

fishes.question: goldfishes are short lived
fishes.explanation: goldfish are one of those longest lived fishes around that can we have, and can live for several decades  under right conditions

fishes.question: farmed salmon get their pink color from artificial injection
fishes.explanation: Both wild and farmed salmon get their pink color from a carotenoid anti-oxidant in their diet called astaxanthin which is traditionally produced by algae that wild salmon consume

fishes.question: whales respond to scream, loud noise made by humans
fishes.explanation: Honestly, we all have our superstitions about what bring the whales close, but most if not all of them are just wishful thinking. For one, the sound barrier between air and water is pretty good, so when you're on shore, chances are the whales can't hear you at all

fishes.question: Goldfish have a three-second memory
fishes.explanation: They have a memory span of at least three months, according to researchers at Plymouth University.

fishes.question: Sharks don't get cancer
fishes.explanation: The 1992 book Sharks Don’t Get Cancer by I. William Lane is to blame for this animal myth. The author used the book’s premise to promote shark cartilage extract for cancer prevention. Cancerous tumors have in fact been found in sharks, disproving this theory.

fishes.question: Piranhas can devour a human being in seconds.
fishes.explanation: Yes, piranhas are fearsome-looking creatures with knife-sharp teeth, but by all accounts they're shy and non-aggressive. In fact, piranhas mostly scavenge for fish, plants and insects in South American rivers and lakes where they live.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: chameleons change colors blend in with their surroundings
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: yes, chameleons can change colors but to regulate their body temperature or to communicate with other chameleons but not to camouflage themselves from it's surroundings

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: chameleons use their array of bright colors as social signal
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: chameleons do not have to exert a lot of effort to blend in with natural state, as they often resembles leaves or branches, but more often they use it to social interactions among them

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: if a baby snake is seen, mother snake could be close by
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: most snakes do not provide parental care like other animals to their young, and they are self sufficient at birth and their own, which means their Parent may not be near them if you spot any baby snakes around

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: snakes can not bite or strike under water
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: a snake can bite or strike above or below water surface, there are many species of snakes which hunts prey from water

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: snakes are aggressive and will chase people
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: while 'aggressive' and 'defensive' can be twisted to mean same things in broader sense, in reality there is no snake that will chase or act aggressively rather 'defensively' towards any human being

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: if a snake is small, it must be a baby
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: while many species of snakes may be small as hatchlings or babies, there are also many species of small, harmless snakes which do not exceed 8 to 15 inches long as an adult

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: when bitten by a venomous snakes, venom should be cut or sucked out
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: it has a potential of doing more harms than good, and is generally not recommended by most snake bite specialist, if not all

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: turtles and tortoise can climb out of their shells
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: a turtle and tortoise can not actually slide or climb out of their shells, it's apart of their skeletal structure and their spinal cord and other internal organs

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: Touching toads gives you warts
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: Toads have wart-like bumps, and human warts are contagious, but you could never catch a wart from a frog or toad. While humans get warts from viruses, the bumps on the amphibians are glands.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: Snakes do not have bones
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: All snakes are vertebrate animals, and do have bones. They have a skull and specialized jaw bones and ligaments, many connected vertebra, or a spinal backbone, and as many as 300-400 pairs of ribs or more, among a few other minor bones present.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: A frog will sit in slowly heated water until it dies
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: This is another useful metaphor, yet untrue. A frog will try to escape a slowly heating pot of water when the temperature goes past its comfort zone.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: You can charm a snake with music
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: Without ears, snakes are unable to hear music or sounds. Instead, they pick up vibrations, warning them of danger and helping them locate prey.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: Snakes unhinge their jaws to swallow their prey
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: A snake swallowing large prey like a mouse or a bird doesn’t unhinge its jaws to swallow the meal. Instead, its jaws extend (because of it’s lower jaw quadrate bone) and its mouth gape increases (by way of flexible jaw bone ligaments) in order to begin swallowing.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: Lizards are loners
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: Recent research has shown some lizards are devoted parents, and mates that can distinguish their kin from strangers; they can even recognize individuals.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: Crocodiles fake tears
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: Researchers found that crocodiles do tear up when they eat, but for still undetermined biological reasons. One theory is that when crocodiles hiss and huff while eating, air pushed through the nose mixes with tears and empties into the eyes.

reptilesAndAmphibians.question: A turtle or tortoise cannot feel when its shell is carved or painted into
reptilesAndAmphibians.explanation: Just as with human fingernails and skin, a turtle or tortoise’s shell has sensitive nerve endings which can feel sensations to what may seemingly be hardened armor also designed to protect them from predators.
